title: Identify Solid Typefaces as a Foundation to Manipulate...
content:
Hey Guys-

Wondering if anybody can lean me in the direction of any existing typefaces similar to these? I've added a few examples, obviously different but I really like the style, especially the solid serif one. They are some custom work by the fantastic crew at Non-Format. I'm wanting to find some abstract solid typefaces similar to do some experimenting for a poster design. Full credit to Non-Format love there work!!

Thanks for any help in advance!

Cheers

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Slab\_samples.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115000118/http:/typophile.com/files/Slab_samples.jpg) | 17.98 KB |
author: J_P_C

comments.content:
This one is in the direction of your top sample:  
 [http://die-gestalten.de/fonts/freefonts/details.html?id=10](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115000118/http:/die-gestalten.de/fonts/freefonts/details.html?id=10 "http://die-gestalten.de/fonts/freefonts/details.html?id=10")  
And it’s free!

For the **Black Devil Disco Club** click yourself through the _similarfonts-section_ at identifont using [Black Boton Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115000118/http:/www.identifont.com/similar?5DD) as a start.

Have a look at chubby pack as well @ [backpacker.gr](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115000118/http:/www.backpacker.gr/). It's not exactly the same but by deleting the counters manually (if it's not too much trouble) you get an interesting result.

George Triantafyllakos - backpacker.gr
For the **Brochures** : There was this [thread](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115000118/http:/typophile.com/node/29460) not long ago.
Thanks guys, really interesting links...checking into them now. Thanks Renko checked the brochure thread- never actually thought of using a heavy stroke to acheive the look, Nice!

these bits look like someone took their type in illustrator, converted to outlines, created an offset path, and then cleaned it up a bit. the fonts are VAG Rounded, some version of Carendon and Myriad Bold.

Below i have applied this process to Myriad Bold. You can see that I can easily derive the result from this with a bit of cleanup:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115000118im_/http:/typophile.com/files/BlackDevilPDH051607_4487.gif)

[FF Extra](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115000118/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_extra/)  
 [Gusto](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115000118/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/stewf/376112212/)  
 [Copal](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115000118/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/monotype/copal_std_solid_ot/)  
 [Acton](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115000118/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/device_fonts/acton/)  
 [Blocks](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115000118/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/creative_alliance/blocks/)  
Or add a heavy stroke to [Frankfurter](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115000118/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/elsner_flake/frankfurter/)

Thanks Paul & Stephen, really enjoying learning the process of creating interesting typography.

Best

Jason from NZ
